title: runtime: onM_gsignalok is wrong on arm
body:
In onM_gsignalok, the LR is lost in the onsignal case during the BL.

diff -r 048e2219734a src/runtime/asm_arm.s
--- a/src/runtime/asm_arm.s	Fri Oct 24 10:58:13 2014 -0400
+++ b/src/runtime/asm_arm.s	Fri Oct 24 16:30:56 2014 -0400
@@ -201,15 +201,17 @@
 	RET
 
 // func onM_signalok(fn func())
-TEXT runtime路onM_signalok(SB), NOSPLIT, $-4-4
+TEXT runtime路onM_signalok(SB), NOSPLIT, $4-4
 	MOVW	g_m(g), R1
 	MOVW	m_gsignal(R1), R2
+	MOVW	fn+0(FP), R0
 	CMP	g, R2
 	B.EQ	ongsignal
-	B	runtime路onM(SB)
+	MOVW	R0, 4(R13)
+	BL	runtime路onM(SB)
+	RET
 
 ongsignal:
-	MOVW	fn+0(FP), R0
 	MOVW	R0, R7
 	MOVW	0(R0), R0
 	BL	(R0)

Austin found this when porting the code to power64. 

This would only affect a call to onM_signalok from the signal stack, which means during
the signal handler. The only calls to onM_signalok arise from throw/gothrow/startpanic.
There are no calls to throw or gothrow in the signal handler, but there is a call to
startpanic. 

This should mean that if you send a program-killing signal to a Go program on arm (for
example kill -abrt) then the RET after the BL (R0) should return back to itself (back to
the RET), which should cause an infinite loop instead of the usual death messages.

Can someone check this and ideally add a test and the fix? I don't want to touch this
code unless we are sure it is actually broken.

Simple test for manual testing:

package main

import "time"

func main() {
	time.Sleep(100 * time.Second)
}


just send it a kill -abrt or type ^\
